OCTOBER TERM, 1784. Maybury Helms’s Lessee against Ruth Howard. EJECTMENT for all that tract of land called Cole’s Harbour, lying in Baltimore county, containing 350 acres. The defendant took defence for Lunn’s Lot. The Jury found a verdict for the defendant. At the trial of the cause nine bills of exceptions were taken. First exception. The plaintiff, to maintain the issue on his part, and to make title to the part of the tract of land called Cole’s Harbour, located on the plat for his pretensions, produced a deed from Charles Carroll to the lessor of the plaintiff, of the 8th of October, 1753, reciting, that he was authorized by the will of Daniel Carroll, his brother, to sell all his lands which should not, in any one tract, exceed 500 acres, and conveys two acres of land called Cole’s Harbour. And the plaintiff produced the will of Daniel Carroll, dated the 12th of April, 1734, authorizing Charles Carroll to sell the land in question; and also the will of Charles Carroll, dated the 1st of February, 1718, by which he devised his lands in Baltimore county, to his sons Charles and Daniel, in fee, as tenants in common. The plaintiff also produced and read in evidence, the certificate of a tract of land called Cole’s Harbour, surveyed for Thomas Cole the 28th of August, 1668, and the grant of the said land to Thomas Cole, the 17th of November, 1668. And the plaintiff produced evidence, that Charles Carroll the father, died in the year 1720 s *58also read in evidence a deed from the last-mentioned Charles Carroll to Jonathan Hanson, dated 9th July, 1711, conveying “ a certain tract of land called Hanson’s Improvement, being taken out of a larger tract, called Cole’s Harbour, and after a resurvey called Todd’s Range and produced evidence to prove that the whole of the said tract which is within the plaintiff’s location of Cole’s Harbour, had been held in virtue of the said ■conveyance, from the time of the conveyance till the present time. And the plaintiff, to prove that the last named Charles Carroll was seised of the tract of land called Cole’s Harbour, produced evidence to prove that the said Carroll had a quarter located on the plats within the lines of Cole’s Harbour; and that an overseer or tenant of Carroll lived on the quarter and cultivated it; and that Carroll died.in such possession of the said, quarter. And the plaintiff, to prove that the devisees of Charles Carroll the father, were possessed of Cole’s Harbour, in like manner as Carroll possessed the same, produced evidence to prove, that after his death they entered in virtue of his will, and were possessed of the quarter an.d cultivated 'ground, in like manner as evidence was offered to prove that Charles Carroll possessed the same ; and that the said devisees being so possessed, Daniel Carroll died in such possession, some time in the year 1734 ; and also produced evidence to prove that Charles Carroll the son, was possessed in like manner in the year 1753, when he executed the deed to the lessor of the plaintiff, and was heir at law to Charles. Carroll the father. . The plaintiff also produced evidence to prove, that on the 1st oi December, 1729, the commissioners of Baltimore town, by virtue of an act of assembly of July, 1729, c. 12. did purchase from the said devisees, Charles and Daniel Carroll, 60 acres of land, expressed to be *59part of Colds Harbour, and lying within the plaintiff’s location of Cole’s Harbour, and did lay out the town of Baltimore on the said 60 acres, which are now possessed under the said purchase. The plaintiff also read in evidence a deed of bargain and sale from Charles Carroll the son, to Joshua Hall, dated the 14th of May, 1737, conveying a tract of land described as being part of Cole’s Harbour. Also proT duced evidence, that no person but Carroll the father, and those who claimed under him, was ever possessed of any part of the tract of land called Cole’s Harbour, as located by the plaintiff, claiming the same as Cole’s Harbour or 'Todd’s Range. The defendant read in evidence a grant for a tract of land called Lunn’s Lot, dated the 20th July, 1673, which tract of land is located on the plat for the defendant’s pretensions, and by the defendant’s location of it on the plat, includes within its lines that part of Cole’s Harbour for which the ejectment was brought. Also produced evidence to prove a title in the defendant to the said tract of land, and a possession in her, and those under whom she claims, between 4Ó and 50 years, of a field called Howard’s Field, located on the plat, and she claiming the same, as part of Lunn’s Lot. And produced evidence of a possession in her and those under whom she claims, for 60 years, of a house called Eager’s Quarter, with a small piece of ground adjoining it, claiming the same as part of Lunn’s Lot; and that no person but the defendant and those under whom she claims, had, to the knowledge of the witness produced, ever set up any claim to that part of Cole’s Harbour, as located by the plaintiff as his pretensions, and contained within the defendant’s location of Lunn’s Lot. And the defendant produced in evidence a certificate of a tract of land called Todd’s Range, whereby “ is resurveyed for Jqmes Todd a tract of land called Cole’s *60Harbour, lyingonthe head of the north-west branch of Patapsco River, now called Todd’s Range’’ dated the 17th February, 1698. And a grant on the same certificate to James Todd, dated 1st June, 1700. Also a deed from James Todd the patentee and his wife to Charles Carroll, dated 16th June, 1701, conveying to him all the remaining part of the tract of land called Todd’s Range. Whereupon the plaintiff’s counsel prayed the direction of the Court to the Jury, that if they believed the testimony offered by the plaintiff, to prove that Charles Carroll (who died in the year 1720) was possessed in the manner above mentioned and described, and that he died in such possession; and if the Jury should be of opinion, that the plaintiff’s location of Cole’s Harbour, beginning at A. thence to I. thence N. N. E. 275 perches, E. 320 perches, thence to the beginning, (see the plat,) is supported, that the plaintiff had made a sufficient title to the part of Cole’s Harbour, agreeably to his pretensions against the defendant claiming Lunds Lot, And the plaintiff’s counsel prayed the opinion of the Court, that the deed from James Todd and wife to Charles Carroll, was not legal and sufficient evidence to disprove the plaintiff’s title as made to Cole’s Harbour, and to show or induce the Jury to be of opinion that the said Charles Carroll entered into and possessed only the said tract of land called Todd’s Range in virtue of the said deed, and merely as a purchase from the said James Todd; and that the said Charles Carroll did not enter into and possess the tract of land called Cole’s Harbour under the title of Thomas Cole the patentee thereof, or under the title of any other person; and therefore that the said Charles Carroll has no title to any part of Cole’s Harbour not included in Todd’s Range. Chase, for the plaintiff,

1. The ejectment is for Cole’s Harbour, and on the plats the plaintiff makes pré*61tensions to part of the tract. The defendant has made . . . pretensions to Lunn’s Lot. It is incumbent on the plaintiff to make title to the part of Cole’s Harbour located on the plat, for his pretensions or claim. '

2. To make title, the plaintiff showed a deed in 1753, from Charles Carroll to him in fee, of the part of Cole’s Harbour laid down on the plat for his pretensions. A will of Daniel Carroll in 1734, by which he appointed Richard Bennett and his brother Charles (who conveyed in 1753 to the plaintiff) his trustees, with power either to sell any of his lands not exceeding 500 acres in any one tract. A will of Charles Carroll in 1718, in which he devised to his sons Charles and Daniel, all his lands in Baltimore county, in fee, as tenants in common.

3. To prove that Charles Carroll died in 1720, seised of Cole’s Harbour in 1718, besides his devise of it in 1718 to his sons Charles and Daniel, and the devise in 1734 by Daniel of his moiety, who sold, and possession of the land in consequence of these devises from the year 1718, the plaintiff showed a deed in 1711, by Carroll the testator, to Jonathan Hanson, for part of Cole’s Harbour, and proved that Carroll in his life-time had a quarter on Cole's Harbour, and cleared and tended in tobacco about 66 or 67 years ago, the tobacco ground which lies over and beyond the N. N. E. line of Todd’s Range, as located by the defendant.

The plaintiff prays the opinion of the Court on these facts to the Jury, that the plaintiff has shown title to the part of Cole’s Harbour agreeable to his pretensions, against the defendant claiming Lunn’s Lot, if the Jury should be of opinion that the plaintiff’s location of Cole’s Harbour from A. to I. and thence N. N. E. 275 perches, E. 320 perches, and thence to A. the beginning, is supported, and if the Jury should believe the testimony offered to prove the possession of Carroll in his life-time before his death in 1720, and that the Court are of opinion, that such possession, if proved, is a sufficient" *62seisin of Carroll in Cole’s Harbour, so that he could deV1Se same » and that the facts stated are sufficient in law to make Carroll seised of Cole's Harhour. t

Argument. It is an established rule of descent, that no man can inherit as heir, i. e. claim a fee by descent, unless he is of the whole blood of the first purchaser.

It is a fundamental rule of evidence in descents, that whoever would make title to an estate, must prove himself heir to the person last seised.

It is a maxim, that seisina facit stipitem, i. e. the seisin of the last possessor, shall be taken for presumption of his being of the whole blood of the first purchasers, without investigating a descent, which, in many cases, Would be impracticable from the length of time. 3 Wils. 526.

Seisin or possession is evidence that the person last seised or possessed, has a title to the land by descent from the first purchaser. It is a fiction of law, i. e. a supposition in law for a good reason, against the real truth of the fact, in a matter which possibly may have been actually performed according to that supposition. Law of Forfeiture, 61.

This fiction, seisina facit stipitem, is founded in public utility, and for the preservation of property; and has been the law in England, ever since the time of Edward I. and has been determined to be so in this state.

The seisin required is not a seisin in law, that is, a right or title to enter, but an actual seisin or possession in fact or deed; and this actual seisin may be by entry of the person, or by his own possession or that of his ancestor’s lessee for years, or by reserving rent from the lessee of the freehold; and such seisin will create him *63an ancestor, or make him a root or stock from which . . all future inheritance by right of blood must be derived,

This fiction, seisina facit stipitem, may be destroyed by showing a right in the land, to which title is made by this fiction, from the first purchaser, or from some person between the first purchaser and the person seised, to the claimant; but without deducing a title in the same land to the person claiming, the showing a prior seisin will not avail, because the subsequent seisin will be evidence of a descent from the person before seised ; e. g. by fiction of law, Carroll, from his seisin of Cole’s Harbour, is supposed to be heir of the whole blood to Thomas Cole. If the defendant can show a title from Thomas Cole, or from any one entitled prior to Carroll, (and proof of seisin by such person before Carroll will be sufficient evidence,) the fiction that Carroll is heir to Cole will be destroyed ; but the showing that Cole conveyed to A. before Carroll was seised, will not be sufficient without deducing a title from A. to the defendant, because the fiction will make Carroll heir to A. as well as to Cole. If this was not the case, the fiction would be useless, and the inconvenience intended to be remedied, would still continue.

The defendant sets up no claim to Cole’s Harbour from Thomas Cole or any other person. The possession of Cole’s Harbour is of an entire thing. j*.

The rule or principle of law possessio fratris de fcedo simplici facit sororem esse hereden., is grounded on the maxim (or fiction) seisina facit stipitem. Co. Litt. 10. b. sect. 3. 11. b. 14. a. sect. 8. 3 Wils. 520.

The rule of descent, that no man can inherit as heir unless he is of the whole blood of the first purchaser, and the rule of evidence in descents, that whoever could make title to an estate, must prove himself heir to the person last seised ; also the maxim, that seisina facit .stipitem being agreed to, the next question is,

*64What is a sufficient seisin of possession in the anees» tor, established on the maxim or fiction of law, seisina Jacit stipitem, as to enable his heir to inherit or not ?

Whatever seisin would be a sufficient seisin of the uncle, (Co. Litt. 11. b. sect. 3.) would entitle the father to the land as his heir; or whatever seisin would be sufficient to entitle the sister, (Co. Litt. sect. 5.) as heir to her brother, will be sufficient in the present or any other ease. 3 Wils. 516.

If the possession of Carroll was not a sufficient seisin, there can be few, very few, stronger cases of seisin in this country.

It cannot be questioned, but the seisin or possession of Carroll in 1711, (when he sold to Hanson, and by his cultivation,) was of Cole’s Harbour. His ownership was exercised over Cole’s Harbour. A seisin of part of an entire thing (as a tract of land) is a seisin of the whole, as far as that whole extends. It (is impossible for two men to be in possession of the same thing at the same time. Two or more men may possess parts of the same thing, as a tract of land, at one time; but the law will adjudge him in the possession of the whole, who hath the right to the possession of the whole. In other words, the law determines the possession of the man who has no right, to be. the possession of the one who hath the right* -

In the present case, Carroll, having possession of part, is in law in the actual possession of. the whole; so as that his heir or devisee may take. But if it be contend-, ed, that he was in possession of Todd’s Range or Cole’s Harbour, so far. as it extends within Todd’s Range, it may be answered, that he claimed Cole’s Harbour; and his possession of the tobacco ground beyond the lines of Todd’s Range, located by Howard, proves that he possessed it as Cole’s Harbour.

We find no.one in possession of Cole’s Harbour as'such, but Carroll and those claiming under him, since the *65year 1711. The defendant sets up no7 claim or possesSion to any part of Cole's Harbour. He makes title and possession to Lunn's Lot. If there is no person in possession, the law requires less seisin or possession. Co. Litt. 15. b. 9 Vin. Abr. 448. pl. 17. 449. pl. 19. As to disseisin, see 1 Reeves, 149. 234 to 246. 250. 2 Reeves, 138. 142. 145. 279. 1 Burr. 107.

If the plaintiff makes title by descent under the maxim seisina facit stipitem, the defendant may, 1st. Deny the seisin or possession of the person from whom the plaintiff claims as seised; 2d. Or show title from such* person from whom the plaintiff claims, to the defendant or any other person j or, 3d. He may show that some person died seised since the person from whom the plaifitiff claims. Booth, 203. 206. But the’ defendant cannot deny the presumption of law, that the person seised is heir to the original grantee, without deducing a title from the grantee, or from some person seised before the person from whom the plaintiff claims, or the rule seisi~ na facit stipitem, will be useless. 15 Vin. Abr. 432. pl. 11. 286. pl. 7. 20 Vin. Abr. 286. pl. 3. 280. pl. 6. Cro. Jac. 221. Yelv. 151. Booth, 275. Vin. (Traverse,) 356.

Showing that Charles Carroll was in possession, is Sufficient evidence in point of law, that he was of the blood of the first purchaser. Wight’s Tenures, 182, 183. Law of Forfeiture, 88, 89.

The fact of making the resurvey, and the recitals in it, ate sufficient proof that Todd was seised of Cole's Harbour.

The question is, whether the deed by fames Todd and Wife, in 1701, to Charles Carroll, passed the residue of Cole’s Harbour not before sold by Todd to Hurst» This question must be decided, as if the dispute was between fames Todd the grantor, and Charles Carroll the grantee, Then grants phall at all times be construed *66and taken more favourably and beneficially; for the benefit and advantage of the grantee, and more strongly for thé barring of the grantors, and according to such intent, as by the words thereof shall appear to have been the true intent of the parties. See the act of 1715, c, 47, s. 9. 2 Bac. Ab. 665. 5 Co. 7. b.

' The matter . and substance of every grant, is but a declaration of the owner’s will to transfer a thing to another, 2 Bac. Abr. 661. A grant in a large sense,' comprehends feoffments, - bargains and sales, &c. 1 Wood’s Convey. 816. Any thing may be granted by the name whereby it is- and has been usually called of latter timeg, within 9 or 10 years, or thereabouts, although it be an improper name, and not the ancient name of the thing, but a name newly acquired. Fitzgibbon, 57. 261. 6 Co. 65. 1 Burr. 28§. Cowp, 600.

Cooke, for the defendant.

The ejectment,was brought for all that tract of land called Cole’s Harbour, containing 550 acres. The plaintiff, to prove that Charles Carroll had a title in fee-simple to the, whole of Cole’s Harbour, and thrgugh.him to derive a title to the lessor-of the plaimiff, showed a conveyance of part of the land to Jonathan Hanson, of 9th June, 1711; and he died in 1720, possessed of the quarter. ■ These possessions might well be, and yet the plaintiff have no possession in any other part. 1 Burr. 113. No presumption can arise that he had any title from Cole. If he claimed by conveyance, he ought to show it; if by descent, he ought to; trace a pedigree. 2 Bl. Rep. 1099. 1 Burr. 273.

The defendant, by showing a prior possession in Todd, removes all such presumption. . Prior possession is a good title, if ho other is found against it.. 2 Sound. 112. Buller, 101. Cowp. 595. Todd having the title, Carroll will be presumed to claim and hold under his deed, unless he shows some other title. Gilb. Law of Evid. 05, 96, 97. The plaintiff proving that no person $%-. *67cept Carroll and those claiming under him possessed Cole’s Harbour or Todd’s Range, does not show he had possession of the whole, nor that the defendant was not possessed of such part as lay in Lunn’s Lot.

Fenings, for defendant.

It is alleged, that if a person die seised, though by wrong, yet he is the stock under the rule seisina fac.it stipitem, and no other can claim.

Thomas Cole was patentee of Cole’s Harbour; after-wards, a certain fames Todd resurveyed it, and ascertained the lines in his resurvey. Todd sold to Charles Carroll Todd’s Range, which was the name the resurvey was called by. Carroll entered, and his tenant or overseer occupied a small bit of ground beyond the resurvey, which the plaintiff suggests was in the original called Cole’s Harbour. Carroll also sold a small piece of land, which in the deed is called Cole’s Harbour, the greatest part lay in the resurvey called Todd’s Range, and a small part, out of Todd’s Range, is what the plaintiff locates as Cole’s Harbour. The plaintiff prayed the direction of the Court, that this was a sufficient seisin of Cole’s Harbour in Charles Carroll, to make a title.

The defendant showed a grant of Lunn’s Lot, younger than Cole’s Harbour, but elder than Todd’s Range, which included that part of Cole’s Harbour (according to the plaintiff’s location) that lay within Todd’s Range; and the defendant proved a possession of part of that land alleged by her to be part of Lunn’s Lot, but by the plaintiff alleged to be part of Cole’s Harbour, upwards of 60 years ; and also other circumstances to induce a presumption that Charles Carroll did not die seised, and the plaintiff alleges he did, and therefore his heir has an incontrovertible title.

Seisin is a fact, and must be determined by the Jury. It must therefore be on the whole evidence, for it would be unheard of that a Jury should determine a fact by the evidence, on one side only. 1 Burr. 113.

*68But if Chirles Carroll had died seised, yet the dc-fondant might have proved h.e was rightfully s.eis.ed; for it is only a rule of eyidence and not .of descent, and obliges the party .tp gp' farther hack. Wrights Tenures, 184. Law of Forfeiture, 32, 33.

Charles Carroll purchased Todd’s Range, and the presumption is, he entered under it. Lunn had a title t§> Lunn’s Lot, which Was elder .than Todd’s Range* It is a strange doctrine, that a man’s running a little over into his neighbour’s land should take away the title from him. Suppose Charles Carro llhni never extended a possession at all into Cole’s Harbour, Lunn’s title eould not have been impeached by him on their pwn principles. Then what makes a title ? They say, by extending a little into Lunn’s Lot; so that a man may always get his peighhour’s land at this rate, by cultivating beyond his lines.

The patent to Lunn put him in possession, for a grant under the great seal amounts to li-v.ery Of seisin,- Then if Carroll claimed by disseisin,- there must have been an ouster as well as .an entry, but none is stated. It was incumbent on the plaintiff to m.ake out a title -to Cole’s Harbour, the ejectment heing .brought for it. This is the reason of so many attempts to make a title, as Todd’s deed to Carroll would not do.

Seisina facit siipitem. If a dying seised, though the seisin was by wrong, is sufficient to make a title in the heir of the person dying seised, and to exclude all proof .of the wrongful seisin of his ancestor,'the rule that a descent .takes away an entry is absurd, for it ought to be that it takes away all other titles. If this was the rule, it w.ould be a perpetual subject of discord; for if a man could enter wrongfully and keep possession till his death, he would transmit the estate without controversy to his descendants.

The meaning of the rule that the person must make himself heir to the person last seised is, that he must make himself heir to the person last rightfully seised *69that is, when none of the same family had a better right than himself, and when a man is rightfully seised, then he is the stock for the succession of his heirs. A disseisor may be rightfully seised against every body but the disseisee.

In order to prove that a man was rightfully seised, in ancient times, proof was required of him to prove that he was of the blood of the first purchaser; and for this purpose he was to trace his descent regularly.. This becoming impossible in process of time, a rule of evidence was substituted as a presumption of such descent, viz. to prove that he was heir to the person who died last seised, which was a presumption of his descent from the first purchaser. 1 Bl. Law Tracts, 214. Wright’s Tenures, 184. Law of Forfeiture, 32, 33.

The rule of being heir to the person last seised, is only a presumptive evidence, and it is the nature of every presumption to be defeated by contrary proof. It is a principle of reason as well as a maxim of law. If it were otherwise, there would be no difference between presumptive evidence and conclusive evidence. Habet presumptio donee probatur in contrarium. To take the rule as a rule of evidence is reasonable; to take it as á rule of descent not to he controverted, would be unjust, and be the greatest incentive to wrongful acts.

2d. Where a man dies lawfully seised, then he becomes the stock from whom future descents are to be traced, and who take jure representationis. Co. Lift. 10. b. For when a man dies seised, you are not to inquire who is the nearest of blood to the person from whom he claims, but who is his own heir, and that heir represents his former ancestor; for the law of descents is not regulated jure propinquitatis, but jure representationis. Example. A. has two sons, B. and C. B. dies leaving a son D. he shall be heir to A. though the younger son is living. This answers 3 Wils. 526. and other similar *70cases-; Cor .'there the'son. being rightfully seised, becomes the stock.

But suppose this cáse had been, that the father of the 'son, or the son himself, had died tortiously seised, would that have prevented any evidence from being given to prove, that though the ancestor died seised, he had not a rightful seisin ?

Suppose, therefore, the evidence had been sufficient to prove that Charles Carroll died seised- of Cole’s Harbour, it could only amount to his being the stock from which his descendants might claim, but would have no operation to prevent others not claiming from him, to dispute his title.

The plaintiff is mistaken in both points. . 1st. He alleges, that if a man dies seised, nt> proof ought to be admitted that he was wrongfully seised ;. and therefore, unless a title can be shown from him, the title is in his heirs, and those claiming under them.'

2d. That no evidence shall ever be given to prove he was not seised, or if given, that it should have no effect, which amounts .to the same thing. This would be .trying a'cause strangely: 1st. Considering any evidence the plaintiff offers, to prove a seisin as conclusive, without regarding any evidence the defendant produced to prove there was no siich seisin, though it is- a fact triable by ■the Jury. 2d. Turning a rule of evidence into a rule of descent not to be controverted, or in other words, first supposing a seisin, without a full examination of the proofs respecting it, and then giving a construction to such seisin contrary to law.

. In 2 Bl. Comm. 209. it is.said, that possession of part creates a seisin, and comes in lieu of the ancient investiture'; but this is only to gain a lawful seisin in fact. The law. 'Casts the inheritance on the heir, which is a seisin in law, and the entry makes a seisin in fact, though the . entry is into part only. Blackstone • is -.treating of . what circumstances will reduce a precedent seisin in *71law to a seisin in fact, and not what shall amount to an ouster to make a disseisin. Nor does he say if a man dies seised, though such seisin was gained by wrong, it shall prevent a person from showing it was by wrong.

Suppose Charles Carroll had been seised, yet such seisin is nothing to others, but would only apply to disputes between those claiming as his heir ; as if he had a sister, and a brother had been born after his father’s death, there the rule of possessio fratris, fkc. would apply.

By their position, if a man has one thousand acres of land, and another buys fifty acres adjoining it, and happens to clear and tend into one acre of the thousand and dies, hisdieir may claim the thousand, under the idea of a dying seised,; and although the party and his ancestors have been in possession, another is to turn him out of possession unless he can show a title from the person dying seised, or trace one regularly from the first patentee.

We have possession; they must show a better title : but any thing may be said to be a better title, if we are. not at liberty to destroy it.

Suppose a suit had been brought against Carroll for a trespass on Cole’s Harbour, could damages have been recovered for more than the extent of his possession ? if not, then there would lie different constructions on it. It is a possession or seisin of the whole if he is to claim, but of part only if he is to lose. There is a warranty in Todd’s deed to Carroll, which shows he only meant to enter under it.

Who would be safe in buying land ? A man encroaches on a small bit of his neighbour’s land, and dies. The neighbour sells, and the purchaser is to be turned out by the heir, under the idea of a seisin. And suppose he has the liberty of deducing his title from the first patentee, 2t lets in all the inconveniences of it,

*72There is’ a difference between evidence to a Jury to operate as a presumption-, and as a bar in' law.- Coivp. 108. 215.

It is sufficient for the defendant to- show that the plaintiff has no title from the first' purchaser, for this destroys the' presumption of his being, of the blood of the first purchaser. The defendant may show a title in any one to defeat the plaintiff’s claim. Comb. 323. Unless the plaintiff shows a good- title, he must fail. 1C! Mod. 415.

It does not appear that James Todd ever had any title in Cole’s Ha bout further than what is comprised! in the resurvey of Todd’s Mange. His’ resurvey could give hitó rio further title to Cole’s Harbour, than what Was! granted by the patent oñ the resurvey,, admitting James Todd claimed Cole’s Harbour as' escheat. The deed from- Todd to Carrollf shows that Carroll never claimed a seisin of any other part than, what was contained within Todd’s Range.

Would-the warranty in Todd’s' deed to Carroll be construed to. extend to land beyond the bounds- of Toddi’s Range ?

If the plaintiff’s doctrine prevail, the onus probahdi will be thrown on the-defendant.

Possession is only matter of evidence, and may be contradicted. Bull. N. A 101. There máy be a disseisin Of part. 9 Vin. 82.

If a stranger enters and severs by méteS and bounds^ possession shall n'ot go to the whole; 1 Brdwnl. 230. that is, the possession of him who has the residue. The Courts of England have construed a disseisin tó be but a dispossession, unless the party made his election to consider if só;

There is á possession- in law and in fact. A wrongful possession cannot extend beyond actual possession ; but if an heir, who before entry has only possession in law, an entry on any part is sufficient to support a possession to the whole.

*73The deed from Todd to Carroll is alone sufficient to destroy the presumption contended for. Certainly the presumption of a man’s having an estate is destroyed by showing the foundation of his title, if such title does not comprehend it,

The defendant has a right, by record, evidence and tradition, to destroy any presumption arising from any recitals in Todd's Range. The deeds of the several conveyances prove Todd never had a title to Cole's Harbour. The acts of 1674 and 1699, for enrolling conveyances, strengthen the proof, as no deed of Cole's Harbour to Todd is to be found on the records. And any record-evidence to prove or disprove Todd's title to Cole's Harbour, is proper for the Jury. The Jury may find deeds if they will, and may inquire of things alleged to be done before the memory of man. Trials per pais, 207, 208. 368. 374. As to recitals in a deed, see 1 Stra. 308.

The Jury only are to make conclusions on the evidence. Any paper on the records is proper evidence to prove a pedigree to deduce a title by ascertaining the person ; so likewise to ascertain the land, where the person is not in dispute.

The plaintiff contends, that the deed from Todd to Carroll conveyed all Cole's Harbour to him, therefore he had a title; and if his location of Cole’s Harbour is right, he ought to recover. This is taking it for granted, that Todd was seised in fee of Colds Harbour.

The plaintiff contends, that Cole's Harbour and Todd's Range are synonymous terms, and are the same tract of land. But suppose Cole's Harbour was not disputed as to its location, and it was admitted to contain only fifty acres, would Carroll be tied down to this, and would he not claim to the extent of the boundaries in his deed of Todd's Range? Suppose also a man resurveys his land, the original containing fifty acres, and the resurvey one *74hundred, and he sells the original tract, will it pass the reSt •

it j3 said a deed must be construed according to the intent of the parties. But the intent must be collected from the words of the deed, and if that is expressed, there is to be no construction dehors. If a man devises Green Acre, no evidence shall be admitted to prove he intended to convey White Acre.
